Do: Put most important insight at top-left where eyes land first
Don't: Bury key metrics at bottom of page
Example: CEO should see revenue trend in 5 seconds without scrolling

Do: Structure: KPIs at top → Trends in middle → Details at bottom
Don't: Start with detailed tables; hide summary at bottom
Example: Top row: 3-5 KPI cards; Middle: Line charts; Bottom: Detailed table

Do: Use size and position to indicate importance
Don't: Equal sizing for all elements; no focal point
Example: Largest chart for most important metric; smaller for supporting

Do: Give elements room to breathe; avoid cramped layouts
Don't: Fill every pixel with data; no margins
Example: Minimum 16px padding between dashboard sections

Do: Align elements to consistent grid for clean appearance
Don't: Random positioning of elements
Example: Use 12-column grid; align chart edges

Do: Design for multiple screen sizes; test on mobile
Don't: Fixed-width layouts that break on small screens
Example: Cards stack vertically on mobile; charts resize

Do: Use same colors for same meanings throughout
Don't: Red means growth in one place and decline in another
Example: Red = negative/alert; Green = positive/growth everywhere

Do: Use 3-5 colors maximum per visualization
Don't: Rainbow of colors with no meaning
Example: Primary brand color + 2-3 supporting colors

Do: Test with colorblind simulation; avoid red-green only
Don't: Rely solely on red vs green for meaning
Example: Use patterns, labels, or blue-orange instead

Do: Use for continuous data showing magnitude
Don't: Categorical colors for numerical ranges
Example: Light to dark blue for low to high values

Do: Use for data with meaningful midpoint (pos/neg)
Don't: Sequential palette for data diverging from center
Example: Blue-white-red for profit/loss or sentiment

Do: Ensure sufficient contrast for readability
Don't: Light text on light background; low contrast
Example: WCAG AA contrast ratio minimum (4.5:1 for text)

Do: Use font size to establish content hierarchy
Don't: Same size for titles, labels, and values
Example: Title: 24px; Subtitle: 16px; Body: 14px; Labels: 12px

Do: Choose readable fonts; limit to 2 families
Don't: Decorative fonts for data; too many font families
Example: Sans-serif for data (Inter, Roboto); consistent weights

Do: Format numbers for readability: 1.2M not 1234567
Don't: Raw unformatted numbers

Do: Label axes clearly; include units
Don't: Unlabeled axes; cryptic abbreviations
Example: Revenue (USD, Millions) not just 'Rev'

Do: Let users click to explore underlying data
Don't: Force users to ask for details separately
Example: Click bar to see breakdown by category

Do: Provide relevant filters; show active filter state
Don't: Too many filters; hidden filter state
Example: Date range, region, segment filters clearly visible

Do: Show details on hover without cluttering view
Don't: Tooltips blocking other content
Example: Hover shows: Date, Value, % Change, Comparison

Do: Connect related charts; filter one affects others
Don't: Isolated charts with no relationship
Example: Clicking segment in pie filters line chart

Do: Every chart needs a clear descriptive title
Don't: Untitled charts relying on context
Example: Revenue by Region (Q4 2024) not just 'Revenue'

Do: Highlight anomalies and key points
Don't: Let users discover insights alone
Example: Arrow pointing to spike with explanation text

Do: Include comparison: vs target, last period, benchmark
Don't: Single number with no reference point
Example: Revenue: $1.2M (↑ 15% YoY, 5% above target)

Do: Clearly show when data was last updated
Don't: Stale data without indication
Example: Last updated: 2024-01-15 08:00 UTC

Do: Cite data source for credibility
Don't: Unknown data origin
Example: Source: Sales Database, Marketing API
